title: Postman Who Gyrocoptered Onto Capitol Lawn Faces Two Felonies
description: Doug Hughes, who delivered letters decrying the role of big money in politics, is only accused of misdemeanors for breaching federal airspace; the felonies are lack of proper license and registration.

title: Islamic State Takes Control Of Ancient City Of Palmyra
description: The city is on UNESCO's list of World Heritage sites, and it gives the militant group access to gas fields and roads across the Syrian desert.

title: Chipping Away At The Mystery Of The Oldest Tools Ever Found
description: How do you prove a rock was actively shaped and used as a tool more than 3 million years ago? Scientists found a kit of more than 140 artifacts in one spot and say the tools' crafters were pre-human.

title: For Israel, Soccer Becomes A Geopolitical Football
description: The head of FIFA visited Israel and the West Bank this week, where Palestinians are petitioning to expel Israel from soccer's governing body — and its biggest international tournaments.

title: Episode 625: The Last Job
description: What if robots did all the work? In today's show, we imagine a world without jobs.

title: McMadness: Activists Pile On At McDonald's Shareholders Meeting
description: From workers calling for higher wages to teachers blasting McDonald's for marketing to kids in schools, a bevy of critics have descended upon the company's headquarters in Illinois this week.

title: Bruce Lundvall, Jazz Record Executive, Has Died
description: The longtime president of Blue Note Records, a lifelong jazz fan, signed artists such as Norah Jones, Joe Henderson and Robert Glasper. He died of complications due to Parkinson's Disease. He was 79.

title: Netanyahu Cancels Palestinian-Only Bus Plan Just Before Scheduled Start
description: NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Lahav Harkov, Knesset reporter for the Jerusalem Post, about the politics around a plan to require Palestinian laborers from the West Bank to ride Palestinian-only buses.

title: FDA Wants To Pull Back The Curtain, Slightly, On Farm Antibiotics
description: The Food and Drug Administration wants to know which farm animals are getting treated most heavily. But the FDA's proposal still falls short of the best European data practices.

title: Energy Companies Step In To Fund STEM Education
description: Many public high schools lack funding for STEM — Science, Technology, Engineering and Math — programs. Energy companies worried about finding future employees are donating to schools.

title: Often The Butt Of Jokes, S.C.'s Giant Peach Is Ripe For Renovation
description: The South Carolina landmark that's both loved and lampooned has gained national celebrity. But the peach's bright paint has soured over the years, so it's getting a makeover — to the chagrin of some.

title: 'My Fair Lady' Couldn't Actually Dance All Night, So These Songs Had To Go
description: The musical has some of the best-known songs in Broadway history, but it originally had other tunes that almost no one knows. Some of those songs were recently performed for the first time in decades.

title: Maine Bill Aims To Make Abuse-Deterrent Painkillers More Affordable
description: Expensive versions of prescription opioids that are tougher to cut, crush and inject are less likely to be abused, legislators hope. But some doctors call the bill well-meant, but ill-advised.

title: Untested Rape Kit Backlog Represents A 'Public Safety Issue' In U.S.
description: NPR's Melissa Block speaks with, Abigail Tracy, a reporter with the news site Vocativ, about the backlog of thousands of rape kits that have yet to be tested around the country.

title: Immigrant Family's Hope On Hold After Promises From The President
description: Six months ago, President Obama announced executive actions that would protect millions of immigrants who are undocumented from deportation. But those actions are on hold pending a lawsuit.
